Dear Family of Blackhawk 2020 Graduate,

As you are aware, our graduation this year will be a virtual ceremony with a recorded video of each graduate being conferred a diploma. We have decided to include immediate family as part of these videos so that we also recognize the many of you that have supported your child in their education.

To limit potential exposure of your family and our staff we ask that only immediate family attend this video recording session. For our purposes immediate family would include those persons living in the same household as the graduate as well as any stepparents or grandparents that wish to attend. Please be mindful that when possible we should avoid exposure to any family members who may be immuno-compromised. All individuals will be required to wear a mask as they enter the building. The graduate and family members will remove their masks when instructed so they are not worn during filming.

Thank you, and we look forward to celebrating the Class of 2020.

CONGRATULATIONS "Women in Science" AWARD WINNERS!!

Mathematics: Sophia Withrow nominated by Heather McCowin
Biology: Gemma DeSanzo nominated by Anita Mensch
Chemistry: Alivia Wooley nominated by Kim Baker

These students were invited along with their parents and nominating teacher to attend a "Women in Science Day" at Seton Hill University. The program began with a Keynote Speaker and then each student then had the opportunity to participate in labs/activities related to the specific academic area in which they received the award. Following the activities, an awards brunch was held where each student received a certificate and was offered a 50% tuition scholarship should they choose to attend Seton Hill following the completion of high school.

Pictured are: Mrs. Anita Mensch, BHS Science Department Chair, Alivia Wooley (Chemistry Award), Sophia Withrow (Mathematics Award), & Gemma DeSanzo (Biology Award). Congratulations to each of these students for their hard work and success in STEM related subjects!

On October 10, Blackhawk students attended an International Diplomacy Simulation sponsored by the U.S. Department of State. Led by a veteran foreign service officer, the students represented the Foreign Ministry of Malil, a fictional country embroiled in a refugee crisis. Working with nations and organizations represented by other Beaver County schools, Blackhawk's diplomatic team negotiated a real-world solution to a simulated border dispute. Following the exercise, the diplomat led a debriefing session and evaluated each stakeholder's methods and outcome.

Pictured in the group photo:

Quinn Borroni
Cora McCowin
Noel Shackelford
Dale Giovengo, Management Officer at U.S. Department of State
Dominic Eicholtz
Molly Yowler
Alaina Cline
